thread.title: Lawmakers Say No to Aisle Seats During Trump Speech
thread.title_full: Lawmakers Say No to Aisle Seats During Trump Speech

author: Susan Milligan
title: Lawmakers Say No to Aisle Seats During Trump Speech
text:

"I'm very disappointed in what the president has been doing, what his administration is doing, and I don't want to convey business as usual, everything is fine. Because everything is not fine," Engel tells U.S. News. "He's been in office 30-some days… starting off with barring immigrants and that ridiculous fence. There's a big cloud with Putin [and] Trump's ties to the Russians. That's very disturbing. Antisemitism is running rampant – they've made some perfunctory statements, but they haven't really grabbed the bull by the horns." 
But most "damning," Engel says, is what he sees as an assault on the free press by the Trump administration. He noted the decision to bar several news organizations from a white House briefing last week. "I didn't think we did that in America," Engel says. "And I don't think I can be quiet as we have this kind of authoritarian [trend] coming upon us. This is far beyond disagreeing with someone's position. This is a whole style. This is authoritarian style, and we don't have that in America." 
There may be less competition all the way around for the aisle seats at the address (lawmakers are not given assigned spots and are not allowed to save seats with personal items). New Jersey Rep. Bill Pascrell, a Democrat, told Fox News he's not sure where he's sitting, but it won't be on the aisle. And a spokeswoman for Texas Democratic Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee told Politico the congresswoman won't shake Trump's hand. 
It's an unusual rebuke of a first-term president. Susan Milligan Senior Writer 
Susan Milligan is a political and foreign affairs writer and contributed to a biography of the late Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, "Last Lion: The Fall and Rise of Ted Kennedy." Follow her on Twitter: @MilliganSusan @
